DOC.HEAD: Cambodians Pray on Christmas, 11 Years After Invasion
With AM-World Christmas, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 200 Cambodians prayed for peace on Christmas Day in their refugee camp in Thailand, exactly 11 years after Vietnam invaded their homeland and sparked the civil war that forced them to flee. ``I pray to God that I can go back to my country,'' said Sau Rany, 22, a religion teacher who wants to be a nun. Inside a church of bamboo and palm leaves, she and other refugees paid respect at an altar with a traditional Cambodian greeting: hands folded before their faces. Besides the altar drooped a Christmas tree with a cellophane star and plastic flowers. No Mass was offered since there are no priests among the refugees, and the foreign priests were away. Sau Rany's father and her brother were killed by the Khmer Rouge, and she fled to the U.N.-aided guerrilla camp in 1984 because of food shortages and other hardships. She said God allows her suffering ``probably to test my endurance.'' Vietnamese divisions invaded Cambodia on Dec. 25, 1978, ending nearly four years of Khmer Rouge rule and installing another communist government. The U.N. border camps hold more than 300,000 refugees from the conflict. The war between the Phnom Penh government and a three-party guerrilla coalition dominated by the Khmer Rouge has intensified since Vietnam's troop pullout in late September. Almost all those at the church were women and their children. ``Usually we have more men here but today they are carrying weapons and food at the border,'' Sau Rany explained. One soldier, Bith Phonn, 42, made it to church after taking leave to look after his wife, eight months pregnant with their ninth child. Bith Phonn displayed the scars from bullet wounds in both thighs and the back of his head. He said he has killed about 10 enemy soldiers in six years of fighting. ``I know it is a sin, but if I don't kill him, he will kill me,'' he said. Relief officials and diplomats say that Prince Norodom Sihanouk's group, which controls Site B, has stepped up conscription because the United States and other countries are supplying aid to the guerrilla armies depending on their size. The U.N. Border Relief Operation and the International commuittee of the Red Cross have told Sihanouk officials they oppose what appear to be efforts to conscript minors. One aid officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a large group of students, some as young as 14, were taken out of the camp in August and earlier this month for military help. The deputy Sihanouk administrator at Site B, Kun Kim Teng, claimed Sunday that all those involved were 18 or older. He said the students went for political, not military, training in August, and those who left this month were carrying food to civilians in newly liberated areas near the Thai border. All were volunteers, he said.
